nodes.text: BinFI can efficiently identify safety-critical bits in machine learning applications under hardware transient faults by exploiting monotonicity in ML computations

Many common ML operations and their compositions exhibit monotonic or approximately monotonic behavior, so error propagation from a bit flip can be modeled by an monotonic or approximately monotonic error propagation function
Using monotonicity, one can search for an SDC boundary bit where flips of higher-order bits cause SDCs and flips of lower-order bits are masked, enabling pruning of the fault injection space

BinFI implements a binary-search-like fault injection algorithm that converts operator outputs to binary, separates 0-bits and 1-bits, and locates SDC boundary bits per element using recursive bisection
BinFI is implemented by extending the TensorFI fault injection tool to support DNN operators and the binary-search injection modes, and is publicly available

Assumptions and fault model: single-fault-per-execution, faults mapped to operator outputs (data path), main memory and register file assumed protected, faults during inference only, single- and multi-bit flips approximated by single-bit analysis

Survey of common ML computations shows monotonicity: Conv/MatMul, ReLu/ELu, pooling, batch normalization in inference, SoftMax derivative positive; some functions like LRN and certain residual compositions are only approximately monotonic or non-monotonic
Approximate monotonicity can cause minor inaccuracies because some small-magnitude faults may violate monotonic ordering, but these cases are rare and unlikely to change safety outcomes substantially
Binary search over sorted fault-impact magnitudes reduces injection trials exponentially compared to exhaustive per-bit injection, by logarithmic dependence on data bitwidth

Evaluation setup: modified TensorFI (TensorFI-BinaryFI), 8 ML models including NN, kNN, LeNet, AlexNet, VGG11/16, Nvidia Dave and Comma.ai steering models, 6 datasets including MNIST, CIFAR-10, ImageNet, German traffic signs, driving frames; 32-bit fixed-point used in major experiments
Experimental results: BinFI identified on average 99.56% of critical bits with 99.63% precision across evaluated benchmarks, significantly outperforming random FI with the same number of trials

Tool modifications: added support for complex DNN operators by using native TensorFlow operators in customized operators and fixing parameter parsing, and added injection modes: random single-bit, binary FI, exhaustive FI

BinFI accurately estimates overall SDC probability: deviations from exhaustive-ground-truth SDC were very small (often near zero for monotonic models), while random FI with same trials showed larger deviations

Performance overhead: BinFI requires about 20% of the fault injection trials compared to exhaustive FI (roughly lo–¥2(bitwidth) behavior), yielding approximately 5X speedup over exhaustive FI; overhead scales logarithmically with bitwidth

Limitations and applicability: BinFI is less effective or has lower precision on models with strongly non-monotonic operators (e.g., LRN); coverage is not 100% so selective protection based on BinFI may miss a small fraction of critical bits but offers practical tradeoffs for safety-critical ML

Conclusion and implications: BinFI is a practical first step to identify safety-critical bits in ML systems enabling targeted low-cost protection and security guidance; future work includes extending to other ML frameworks, more safety-critical domains, and selective protection strategies
